awd_titl_txt: An Efficient Framework for Channel State Dissemination and Network Synchronization
awd_abstract_narration:
With the rapid proliferation of wireless devices in the last decade, it has become increasingly important to efficiently utilize limited spectrum resources through close coordination of devices in the network.  While several advanced techniques have been developed recently to address this problem, these techniques require an accurate and consistent view of the channel states as well as some degree of synchronization among the devices in the network to be effective. The research plan in this project is focused on developing an analytical framework and efficient techniques for channel state dissemination and network synchronization to enable close coordination of devices in a network and efficient utilization of the channel resources. The proposed research is based on the view that, in order to determine the best use of the spectral and temporal resources available to the network, channel state estimation and dissemination should be performed continuously as part of the normal network operation. By estimating and disseminating network channel state information continuously through existing network traffic, devices in the network can adaptively determine an appropriate network structure and mitigate the effects of interference to facilitate efficient communication under current and predicted channel states.

The foundational nature of the research plan makes it broadly applicable in a wide range of wireless communication systems such as cellular networks, wireless local area networks, vehicular networks, and emergency communication systems. The analytical framework and techniques for efficient channel state dissemination and network synchronization developed on this project will impact emerging wireless communication systems such as informed-transmitter multi-input multi-output (MIMO), cognitive radio, cooperative relaying, distributed transmission, and interference alignment.  The proposed research will establish a solid theoretical foundation for understanding the limits of minimum-staleness channel state dissemination and clock synchronization in wireless networks and will also include experimental verification through testbed implementations of the channel state dissemination and network synchronization techniques.

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of this project was to develop efficient techniques for channel state information (CSI) dissemination and network synchronization in order to enable close coordination of the devices in a wireless network and enable efficient utilization of the channel resources. The project focused on (a) developing a framework and practical methods for efficiently estimating and disseminating CSI in wireless networks and (b) developing low-overhead precise network synchronization techniques that can be embedded in existing network traffic.

 

The project resulted in several significant accomplishments. First, a new timestamp-free synchronization technique was developed in which synchronization information is conveyed between devices implicitly at the physical layer through the timing of messages. The fundamental accuracy limits of this approach were analyzed and experimental studies were conducted to verify the results. The published experimental studies demonstrated synchronization accuracies on the order of one nanosecond with low cost off-the-shelf hardware. For wireless networks with more than two devices, consensus synchronization methods were also studied. A key outcome of this investigation was the development of a new monotonic mean squared convergence criteria and an analysis of the convergence properties of random pairwise consensus synchronization using timestamp-free methods in general wireless networks.

 

Another significant accomplishment of this project was the development of fundamental limits and efficient schedules for estimating and disseminating CSI in wireless networks. A new framework was developed for analyzing the staleness of time-slotted schedules that estimate and disseminate CSI to all nodes in a fully connected network, hence achieving global CSI knowledge throughout the network. Fundamental lower bounds on the achievable staleness in this setting were derived, and efficient dissemination protocols were developed and demonstrated to achieve staleness close to these limits. A key outcome of this investigation was explicit engineering guidelines on the feasibility of tracking global CSI as a function of network size, the size and composition of the packets exchanged between the nodes, the packet error rate, and the channel coherence time.

 

The work on analyzing the staleness of CSI was also generalized to consider the staleness, i.e., the "age", of arbitrary information sources under general network topologies. For example, autonomous vehicles may wish to exchange timely information about their position and velocity with other nearby vehicles to maintain safe distances and avoid collisions. In this context, fundamental lower bounds for the peak and average age were derived and were found to be a function of key graph properties including the connected domination number of the graph and the average shortest path length. Achievability results were also developed through an explicit algorithm for constructing near-optimal status update schedules. A key outcome of this investigation was a more general understanding of the fundamental limits of the age of information in general multihop networks where nodes in the network are both sources of information as well as monitors of information.

 

Finally, another important outcome of this project was the education of several graduate and undergraduate students in the subjects of wireless communications, signal processing, estimation theory, dynamic systems, and queueing theory. Undergraduate students participated in the project through the NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program. The graduate and undergraduate students involved in this project all authored or co-authored peer-reviewed papers and presented their results at major conferences.
